awd_titl_txt: Adaptive QM/MM Methods for Proton Transfer in Complex Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Hai Lin of the University of Colorado at Denver is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to develop and apply computational methods to study proton transfer in biological environments.  Just as every day we walk through doors of houses, offices, schools, and shops; every minute, ions that are essential to life pass through doors of biological cells. These doors on the surface of cells are called ion channels and transporters. Situated in cellular membranes, these special  proteins control which ions move across the membrane and when. Among these proteins are the CLC proton/chloride antiporters, which regulate the influx of protons and the outflow of chloride ions in a coupled manner. Details of how the CLC proton/Chloride antiporters work in transferring protons remain elusive.  Moreover, it is still under debate if (and how) the proton interacts with chloride ions during its journey through the translocation pore. Professor Lin and his research team, which includes two undergraduate students, seek answers to these questions through computer simulations. They are developing advanced computational techniques that combine quantum- and classical-mechanical models.  They then apply these methods to study the CLC transporters. As malfunctioning doors can block us from reaching our destination, malfunctioning ion channels and transporters can disrupt normal life processes and cause diseases. The research by the Lin group seeks to deepen our understanding of how the CLC transporters work at a fundamental, molecular level, which may, in turn, assist the development of novel therapies for diseases related to these protein malfunctions.

The Grotthuss-shuttling mechanism for proton transfer involves dynamical reorganizations of covalent and hydrogen bonds. While reactive force fields (also called molecular-mechanics, or MM) and multistate empirical valence bond models are efficient in treating water dissociation and proton hopping.  The extension of these models in complex environments is challenging because of the rapidly increasing number of potential parameters needed to account for more valence configurations. Moreover, electronic-structure information is missing for the bond breaking/forming processes, which are described ideally by quantum mechanics (QM). QM simulations are limited to small model systems (~hundreds of atoms) due to high computational costs. The Lin group is developing novel adaptive-partitioning QM/MM methods for proton transfer in complex environments. The adaptive-partitioning schemes feature an on-the-fly smoothly updated mobile QM region that follows the proton wherever it goes. As such, a finite-size QM region becomes infinite and can, in principle, sustain simulations as long as needed. The new algorithms are applied to the study of a prototype CLC antiporter from E. coli. With on-the-fly computed QM/MM potentials and an explicit treatment of protons, the dynamics simulations explore the hydrophobic pore hydration, water wire formation, proton translocation, and chloride ion protonation in the CLC antiporter.

por.por_cntn:
All organisms must import nutrients and export wastes in order to stay alive. At the cellular level, the intake and discharge are usually regulated by transport proteins embedded in cell membranes. Detailed knowledge of how transport proteins operate at the molecular level is vital to our understanding of life processes and can help the development of therapeutics that cure diseases caused by malfunctions of these proteins.

 

Among the transport proteins are the CLC proton/chloride antiporters, which regulate the influx of chloride ions and the outflow of proton in a coupled manner. However, details remain elusive regarding the dynamic movement of the transferring proton. For example, it was very much under debate if (and how) the proton interacted with chloride ions along its journey through the translocation pore. Professor Hai Lin from the University of Colorado Denver and his research team, which includes undergraduate and MS students, are determined to find the answers to these questions through computer simulations.

 

In this project, Lin and coworkers have developed and applied advanced multiscale computational techniques to study the CLC proteins. In particular, by combining quantum and classical models in a dynamic, flexible, and self-consistent way, they formulated novel adaptive quantum-mechanics/molecular-mechanics (QM/MM) algorithms to describe proton transfer through the pore of transport proteins. This is the first set of adaptive algorithms that are capable of treating proton transfer in a highly heterogeneous environment as oppose to the homogeneous bulk aqueous solution. Their work also revealed that the migrating proton can indeed bond to the chloride ion to form hydrogen chloride in the CLC pore, albeit only for a brief period of time. The extremely unusual formation of hydrogen chloride had been speculated almost a decade ago on the basis of experiments and simple quantum-model calculations, but it is only till now that such a process is explicitly shown for the first time by the Lin group in dynamics simulations employing realistic multiscale models.   

 

The new algorithms have been implemented in the computer code QMMM developed by Lin and coworkers. Several adaptive algorithms are also now available in other programs such as ChemShell, FlexMD, and Janus, making them assessible to a wider community. The project has provided excellent opportunities to engage undergraduate and MS students in research. Among the students who have been involved in this project, 6 are women, 4 are minorities, and 3 are first-generation college students. Five of them published in peer-reviewed journals, and 9 have presented in professional conferences. The rigorous training through research prepared the students for diverse future careers, including 4 students entering PhD programs, 4 going to medical schools, 1 becoming a K-12 teacher, and 2 working as lab technicians. The project also helped to establish a partnership between the Lin lab and the local Cherry Creek High School, through which science and math K-12 teachers participated in summer research activities. The teachers applied what they learned through the research to curriculum improvement, fostering better education for the future generations.
